descendants.content:
@kim_harding
We could do that but people won't be able to go to the Olympics or Taylor Swift concerts...

So the people decided the laws of nature didn't apply to humans and ... ignored them :)

alas for the sliver of species left on the planet, those same people will find out they won't be able to fly to Taylor Swift concerts or attend the Olympics anyway, when they collapse civilisation under the weight of their own hubris I.e inaction on climate change.

account.note:
I am here to learn and face the truth, not avoid it and sometimes this can alas lead to confrontation when others prefer the latter to the former.

Matrix Account: @hanrahan:matrix.org

fields.name: How hot is it?
fields.value: https://www.globalwarmingindex.org/

descendants.content:
@kim_harding
Moreover it is a bad idea, it would create a rebound effect.
As it doesn't address the root cause we'll just continue to release as much if not more (rebound effect) CO2 in the atmosphere.

The only true solution is to slow down everything.

@kim_harding

I tend to agree, that there must be some cutting down. But ig someone is willing to pay to sequester carbon so they can emit carbon, and they wouldnt otherwise purchase that sequestering, who cares, let them. No harm done. They should still be required, overall to be in the negative.

descendants.content:
@freemo Clearly, you don't understand the problem. It is not a case of "cutting down", the science is clear, we have to stop the extraction and release of fossil carbon.

The laws of physics don't care about political opinion, there is no other option (or other planet we can move to).

descendants.content:
@kim_harding

"Part of the clean-up process" is debatable. Carbon sequestration often doesn't work and can even increase emissions, all while greenwashing and diverting funds and subsidies away from more useful environmental efforts.

So yes, the first step is to stop digging and stop burning!

https://www.newscientist.com/article/2308935-most-schemes-to-capture-and-reuse-carbon-actually-increase-emissions

@freemo

card.title: Most schemes to capture and reuse carbon actually increase emissions
card.description: Carbon capture and utilisation technologies, which aim to pull carbon dioxide from the air and use it for emissions-lowering processes, emit more carbon than they remove

descendants.content:
@katlin

The assumption here is if you sequester and it doesnt work, then it shouldnt count as carbon credit.

What Im asking is, if someone sequesters and can show it does, actually, work, should that be allowed as a means to offset their carbon credit?

@kim_harding

descendants.content:
@freemo @kim_harding

That's a reasonable question to ask. I think there's always a role to play for "clean-up" processes which actually work, as long as they don't distract us from the urgent task of cutting down and phasing out fossil fuels and as long as they don't breed complacency with false techno-optimism

@katlin

Agreed.

In my mind the approach would be simple.. figure out how much co2 people/companies can release and ensure the atmospheric CO2 will go down as a result.

Everyone then must meet that number or below. If they can show successful sequestering they get to subtract that number from what they produce. As long as everyone stays below their allowed threshold, we are golden.

@kim_harding

descendants.content:
@katlin
Yes, I agree, the magical machines are just Greenwash.

However, it wasn't what I had in mind when I said, "part of the clean-up process", I was thinking more about the protection of natural carbon sinks, which are being overwhelmed but the level of pollution that humans are producing

descendants.content:
@kim_harding

There is also the possibility to simultaneously reduce greenhouse emissions while expanding natural carbon sinks by transitioning away from animal agriculture and #rewilding existing farmlands. It's really a no-brainer but unfortunately the usual barriers of capitalism, corporate greed, political apathy, etc. stand in the way.

https://arstechnica.com/science/2022/01/plant-based-diets-rewilding-provides-massive-opportunity-to-cut-co2

@robloblaw

card.title: Plant-based diets + rewilding provides “massive opportunity” to cut CO2
card.description: This "double-dividend" can help rich nations significantly cut their emissions.

descendants.content:
@katlin @robloblaw

As an ecologist, I would say that it is not that simple. A lot of "rewilding" projects are simply gardening. Yes, we should move to more sustainable agricultural systems, and those do involve animal husbandry as a part of the system.

But that doesn't solve the problem of the release of fossil carbon into the atmosphere. We have to stop that as fast as possible if we are to maintain a liveable planet.

descendants.content:
@kim_harding
We need to do both. Move to a zero carbon economy as fast as possible AND draw down historic emissions. Ban new fossil fuel extraction, urgently fix leaks in the methane extraction and transport industries. More:
https://drawdown.org/solutions

Some industries will need point source emissions capture and storage. Cement is a massive CO2 source, but is needed for green infrastructure.

Current carbon offset systems are fraud.
https://pluralistic.net/2023/10/31/carbon-upsets/
1/2

card.title: Drawdown Climate Solutions Library
card.description: Drawdown Solutions reduce greenhouse gases by avoiding emissions and/or sequestering carbon dioxide already in the atmosphere.
card.image_description: Clouds with text which reads The World's Leading Resource for Climate Solutions

descendants.content:
@kim_harding
The only current economically viable direct air carbon capture solutions that could scale to useful levels are biochar and enhanced weathering. Which work better together:
https://youtube.com/watch?v=bHsCes9tBXk

And can be combined with other regenerative agriculture/permaculture techniques.
2/2

card.title: - YouTube
card.description: Enjoy the videos and music you love, upload original content, and share it all with friends, family, and the world on YouTube.

descendants.content: @kim_harding and don't forget the industrial use of biofuel. It is as bad if not worse than fossil carbon due to its lower calorific value.

account.note: Not a lot to say about myself. Worked as GP in valleys, then public health something to do with data of health events. Ignored mainly, you're advised to do the same. Meanwhile if you fancy seeing what I'm thinking this is quite a good place happy to be corrected as I don't know as much as I think I do. It's a common male fault. 🤣
